refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: Builds the solution defined in the file at SOLUTION_DEFINITION. Updates the solution if it exists.

refsect1.title: USAGE
refsect1.para: OPTIONS refers to the command-line options described below. SOLUTION_DEFINITION refers to a solution definition file, see the Solution Definition File Reference at for more information.

refsect1.title: OPTIONS
refsect1.para: Command options are listed in alphabetical order.

listitem.para: Specifies the directory and filename SOLUTIONSTUDIO_CONF of the solutionstudio configuration file. The default value is /etc/solutionstudio/solutionstudio.conf. See the solutionstudio.conf(5) man page for SolutionStudio configuration options.
Clears the shared cache of downloaded files. See solutionstudio.conf(5) man page for more cache options.

Forces a SolutionStudio MODULE to execute, even if the module would ordinarily be skipped for optimizations in speed. Forcing a module forces its children recursively. This option can be specified more than once, as in the example below:
--force MODULE1 --force MODULE2 --force MODULE3
See the MODULES section below for more information.
Specifies a directory containing SolutionStudio modules PATH. The default path is the system path. This option can be specified more than once; for example:
--lib-path PATH1 --lib-path PATH2 --lib-path PATH3
See the MODULES section below for more information.

Displays a list of SolutionStudio modules including name, description, and child modules, then exits without building the solution. Note: SolutionStudio requires a solution definition on the command line when using this option, for example:
solutionstudio --list-modules SOLUTION_DEFINITION
See the MODULES section below for more information.
Specifies the directory and filename PATH to which SolutionStudio writes logging information of Level 5 detail. The default path is /var/log/solutionstudio.log. See the command option --log-level.
--log-file PATH
Specifies the level of detail logged to the console during a build. There are six levels N (0 to 5) with Level 3 being SolutionStudio's default level.

LEVELS
* Level 0: Displays errors only. * Level 1: Displays build status. * Level 2: Displays module status. See MODULES. * Level 3: Displays file download and creation status. * Level 4: Displays file copy and deletion status. * Level 5: Displays complete debug-level status.
Setting the log level to 0 will prevent all logging except errors to the screen, while levels 1 to 5 have increasingly more detail about the build process.
Disables validation of SOLUTIONSTUDIO_CONF and SOLUTION_DEFINITION during the build process.

Specifies a directory PATH where SolutionStudio can locate shared program data such as XML schema files. The default path is /usr/share/solutionstudio/. This option can be specified more than once, as demonstrated below:
--share-path PATH1 --share-path PATH2 --share-path PATH3

Prevents a MODULE from executing, even if the module would ordinarily be executed due to changes in input, output or other factors. Skipping a module skips its children recursively. This option can be specified more than once, as in the example below:
--skip MODULE1 --skip MODULE2 --skip MODULE3
See the MODULES section below for more information.

Performs SOLUTIONSTUDIO_CONF and SOLUTION_DEFINITION validation only; it does not build the solution. The option also displays the complete SOLUTION_DEFINITION file after resolving macro and include elements.

refsect1.title: VARIABLES
refsect1.para: SolutionStudio command options, where indicated, use three variables: MODULE, PATH and SOLUTIONSTUDIO_CONF.

listitem.para: The id of a SolutionStudio module. See the MODULES section, below, for more information.
A local file path. SolutionStudio resolves paths relative to the current working directory.
The directory and filename of the SolutionStudio configuration file.

refsect1.title: MODULES
refsect1.para: A module performs an individual step in the build process, such as downloading software packages or creating ISO images. To display a list of available modules use the option --list-modules with the solutionstudio command. Note: SolutionStudio requires a solution definition on the command line when using this option, for example:

On subsequent builds of the same solution, SolutionStudio automatically determines whether a module can be skipped in favor of using cached data from a previous build. Users can override the default determination using the --skip and --force options.
Developers can write custom SolutionStudio modules and direct SolutionStudio to use them via the --lib-path solutionstudio command option.
